title: 'My Strictly success has silenced racists' says former England star Alex Scott
text:

Alex Scott says she’s shown racist trolls the red card...thanks to her Strictly success.

Former England football star Alex, 35, now a pundit, says she’s only had kind comments online since hitting the dance floor on the BBC show.

She said: “The support I’m receiving on the back of Strictly is super positive. It’s nice and refreshing.”

The Strictly fan, who said it was her dream to appear on the show, added: “For them to message that kind of stuff rather than putting me down is really nice.”

Mixed-race Alex, England women’s second most-capped player, was targeted while analysing men’s games on Sky Sports and the Beeb.

(Image: Supplied by WENN)

But the defiant star - partnered with pro Neil Jones - said: “I know I’m inspiring people. That’s why I didn’t quit football. I knew the change I was making.”

Opening up about the abuse, Alex said: “I had all of it, for being a woman on TV, for being a woman of colour on TV, that I’m ticking a box, death threats. The lot.”

(Image: Supplied by WENN)

Alex became Sky’s first female pundit on men’s Premier League matches last year. And she was a mainstay of the BBC’s World Cup coverage at Russia 2018.

She has been impressing with her skills on Strictly. However last night she was partnered with Kevin Clifton for her couple’s choice dance to Ghostbusters in the Halloween Special after

Neil injured himself rehearsing yesterday.

In a second upset, Will Bayley hurt a leg in rehearsals so also coudn’t dance. He and Janette get a free pass to next week.

Alex and now single Neil, 37, have formed a close bond - but brushed off talk they are more than friends.
description: The Sky Sports pundit has received support and kind messages following success on the BBC dancing competition, after speaking out on the racist trolling she experienced previously
